newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean won ends lower despite BOK intervention.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean won ends lower despite BOK intervention.

text.p: The won closed lower against the U.S. dollar despite a series of interventions by the central bank on Thursday, dealers said.
The won closed value-tomorrow trading at 874.40 after opening at 870.00. It hit a low of 874.90.
The Bank of Korea (BOK) offered to sell $20 million each at 887.00 in three-month and 899.00 in six-month forward trading in the early morning session. This failed to boost the won.
Just before the lunch break, the BOK sold dollars in value-spot trading after the won fell to an 84-month low of 875.30.
A BOK official said the central bank would neither confirm nor deny its interventions in the market.

South Korea's won/dollar trading is divided into value-spot and value-tomorrow based on the method of cash settlement. In value-tomorrow, cash settlements are made the day after the transaction and after two business days in value-spot. The value-tomorrow rate is regarded as the representative rate.

Without signs of improvement in the won's demand and supply, the local unit will continue to fall in line with the dollar's strength on world markets, dealers said. Friday's mid-rate is expected to be pegged at 874.00 against Thursday's 868.70.
